items.message:
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Areas most at risk include low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.
Further flooding is possible throughout Monday and into Tuesday as river levels have risen due to the rainfall over the weekend.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: High river levels this evening, 12 January 2026, into to tonight may lead to flooding. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Church Laneham to Rampton Road. There is further light rainfall forecast over the next 12 hours. River levels at Torksey Gauge are rising slowly and expected to remain high until 14/01/2026. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated after 09:00AM tomorrow morning, 13 January 2026, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent rainfall and snow melt. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.

River levels at Pillings Lock Gauge will remain high over the next few days. There is minimal further rainfall forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation & checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 09:00AM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
River levels are high on the River Churn particularly around Cerney Wick. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, on Monday 12 January. The weather forecast for today, is mostly dry with a few showers in places. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, midday, on the 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Flooding is expected.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected on the River Cherwell especially near Enslow, Thrupp and Kidlington. The high river levels are due to the heavy rainfall we saw on Thursday 8 January. The water has now made its way down the river. The weather forecast today is mostly dry with a few showers in places. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, midday, on the 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. Minimal further rainfall is forecast today, 12/01/2026. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, midday, on the 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
This information is correct as of 16:00 on 12th January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately  5 centimetres of water on the road. In response to the levels Highways have closed the causeway. There are currently no issues on the Earith and Welney causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Flooding is possible today as a result of heavy rainfall from Storm Goretti. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. 
 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. 
Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. 
This message will be updated by 08:00AM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected. However, rain Tuesday and again Thursday could cause flood risk to return. It is probable we will re-issue this Flood Alert Tuesday. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and work with emergency services and local authorities.

Rising river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 12 January 2026 due to overnight rain combined with snow melt. 
Flooding may affect low lying land & roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury; including Dog Lane Bewdley, Stourport, Diglis & Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains affect the racecourse & Worcester CCG. PLP should be installed. New St Gate closed at Upton upon Severn. Predicted peaks:- Worcester 3.6m to 3.9m on 12/01 PM, Diglis 3.4m to 3.6m on 12/01 PM, Kempsey Yacht Club 5.6m to 5.8m on 12/01 PM, Saxons Lode 4.3m to 4.6m on 13/01 PM. Other gauge locations are not forecast to exceed Flood Alert thresholds. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

High river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 12 January 2026 due to overnight rain and snow melt. 
Flooding may affect low lying land and Squires Walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation Scheme is currently operational from 12/01/2026. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.6m to 5.8m 12/01 PM. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Minimal rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. River levels at Willington and Shardlow Gauge are likely to remain high until 15/01/26. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 13/01/26 or as the situation changes.

River Severn bankfull at White Abbey, floodplain may be filling at Hayes Basin. Predicted peaks:- Crew Green 5.5m to 5.8m on 12/01 PM, Montford 4.6m to 4.9m on 13/01 AM, Welshbridge 2.5m to 2.7m on 13/01 PM, Buildwas 3.5m to 4.0m on 13/01 PM, Bridgnorth 2.7m to 3.2m on 14/01AM. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 9:00AM on 13 January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message: High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible in the West Dorset area. Groundwater levels are high in response to heavy rainfall earlier in December. Levels are slowly falling but remain high, and flooding of fields and roads is still possible. No significant rainfall is forecast for the next few days. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 13th January 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Stour from Sudbury to Stratford St Mary and Dedham
items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on Monday 12th January 2026. River levels are high following heavy rainfall from Storm Goretti. Areas most at risk are riverside areas of the River Stour between Sudbury and Dedham. In Langham, local roads are prone to flooding and cars may become stranded on Sky Hall Hill Road, Wick Road and Lower Farm Road. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are not expecting the situation to escalate. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10am Tuesday 13th January or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the South Winterbourne Valley
items.message: High groundwater levels are still expected to cause flooding. Flooding is still expected from 6th January 2026 onwards. Groundwater levels in West Dorset remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Winterbourne Abbas, Winterbourne Steepleton, Martinstown, Winterbourne Monkton, Winterbourne Herringston and Winterbourne Came. The groundwater level at the Kingston Russell borehole has fallen to 116.68m, and is expected to fall further over the next few days. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected. Roads may be damaged by floodwater. Any intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding. We are closely monitoring the situation. If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 13th January 2026, or as the situation changes.
